Outline of the evaluation process

Data Augmentation

First, you produce a list of AugmentedSample, either by loading an existing one, or using tools the library provides to build you it from raw data, or by creating your own from scratch.

class countergen.types.AugmentedSample

Where a Variation is defined as follows.

class countergen.types.Variation(text, categories)
property text

Alias for field number 0

property categories

Alias for field number 1

Model Loading

Second, you load your model and turn it into a ModelEvaluator.

countergen.types.ModelEvaluator

Callable that returns the performance of a model given an input and expected outputs.

Model Evaluation

Third, you pass your list of AugmentedSample and your ModelEvaluator into the following function:

countergen.evaluate(samples: Iterable[AugmentedSample], model: Callable[[str, List[str]], float], aggregator: StatsAggregator[T] = AveragePerformancePerCategory(use_geometric_mean=False)) → T

By default, it will return the average performance on each kind of data. You can specify other ways to aggregate the performance on each variation by passing another StatsAggregator.

Alternatively, if you just want to print or save the results, directly call on of the following:

countergen.evaluate_and_print(samples: Iterable[AugmentedSample], model: Callable[[str, List[str]], float], aggregator: StatsAggregator[T] = AveragePerformancePerCategory(use_geometric_mean=False))
countergen.evaluate_and_save(samples: Iterable[AugmentedSample], model: Callable[[str, List[str]], float], path: str, aggregator: StatsAggregator[T] = AveragePerformancePerCategory(use_geometric_mean=False), also_print: bool = True)

And that’s it! countergen and countergentorch provides to generate variations, load models easily, and edit them to decrease performance gaps between different categories. Click on Next to know more.
